perturbation.original_text: WHEREAS, Movado Group, Inc. (the "Company") and the Trustees of the Grinberg Family Trust (the "Trust") entered into a Policy Collateral Assignment And Split Dollar Agreement, dated as of December 5, 1995 (the "Split Dollar Agreement"); and
perturbation.changed_text: WHEREAS, Movado Group, Inc. (the "Corporation") and the Trustees of the Grinberg Family Trust (the "Beneficiary") entered into a Policy Collateral Assignment And Split Dollar Agreement, dated as of December 5, 1995 (the "Split Dollar Agreement"); and
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'Company' to 'Corporation' and 'Trust' to 'Beneficiary' without definition creates confusion about the entities involved, potentially leading to disputes over obligations and rights.

perturbation.original_text: 7. Company Default. In the event of a "Company Default" (as defined below), the Trust shall have the right to require the Company to cure the Company Default by notifying the Company in writing within sixty (60) days after its receipt of notice of a Company Default, or if later, within thirty (30) days after a Trustee becomes aware of the Company Default. If the Company fails to cure the Company Default within sixty (60) days after being notified by the Trust of the Company Default, the Trust shall have the right to require the Company to transfer its interest in the Policy to the Trust. The Trust may exercise this right by notifying the Company, in writing, within sixty (60) days after the Company Default occurs. Upon receipt of such notice, the Company shall immediately transfer ownership of the Policy to the Trust and the Company shall thereafter have no rights with respect to the Policy. The Trust's failure to exercise its rights under this Section 7 shall not be deemed to release the Company from any of its obligations under this Agreement, and shall not preclude the Trust from seeking other remedies with respect to the Company Default. For purposes of this Agreement, a "Company Default" shall be deemed to have occurred with respect to the Policy if the Company fails to pay a premium on the Policy as required under the terms of this Agreement within sixty (60) days after the due date for such premium, or if the Company processes or attempts to process a policy loan, or a complete or partial surrender, or a cash value withdrawal without prior written approval from the Trustees of the Trust. The Company shall notify the Trustees of the Trust within five (5) business days of any event which constitutes a Company Default.
perturbation.changed_text: 7. Corporation Default. In the event of a "Vendor Default" (as defined below), the Beneficiary shall have the right to require the Corporation to cure the Vendor Default by notifying the Corporation in writing within sixty (60) days after its receipt of notice of a Vendor Default, or if later, within thirty (30) days after a Trustee becomes aware of the Corporation Default. If the Corporation fails to cure the Vendor Default within sixty (60) days after being notified by the Beneficiary of the Vendor Default, the Beneficiary shall have the right to require the Corporation to transfer its interest in the Policy to the Beneficiary. The Beneficiary may exercise this right by notifying the Corporation, in writing, within sixty (60) days after the Vendor Default occurs. Upon receipt of such notice, the Corporation shall immediately transfer ownership of the Policy to the Beneficiary and the Corporation shall thereafter have no rights with respect to the Policy. The Beneficiary's failure to exercise its rights under this Section 7 shall not be deemed to release the Corporation from any of its obligations under this Agreement, and shall not preclude the Beneficiary from seeking other remedies with respect to the Vendor Default. For purposes of this Agreement, a "Vendor Default" shall be deemed to have occurred with respect to the Policy if the Corporation fails to pay a premium on the Policy as required under the terms of this Agreement within sixty (60) days after the due date for such premium, or if the Corporation processes or attempts to process a policy loan, or a complete or partial surrender, or a cash value withdrawal without prior written approval from the Trustees of the Trust. The Corporation shall notify the Trustees of the Trust within five (5) business days of any event which constitutes a Corporation Default.
perturbation.explanation: Using 'Vendor Default' and 'Corporation Default' interchangeably when the contract initially defined the entity as 'Company' and later as 'Corporation' creates ambiguity. The 'Company' and 'Corporation' might now be the same or different entities. The change of terms leads to potential disputes about what constitutes a default and who is responsible for curing it.

perturbation.original_text: 13. Administration. If this Agreement is determined to be subject to ERISA, it shall be administered by the Company, or its designee (the "Plan Administrator"), which shall be the "named fiduciary" of this Agreement for purposes of ERISA. The Plan Administrator shall have the authority to make, amend, interpret, and enforce all rules and regulations for the administration of this Agreement and decide or resolve any and all questions, including interpretations of the Agreement, as may arise in connection with this Agreement. In the administration of this Agreement, the Plan Administrator from time to time may employ agents and delegate to them or to others (including executives of the Company) such administrative duties as it sees fit. The Plan Administrator from time to time may consult with counsel, who may be counsel to the Company. The decision or action of the Plan Administrator (or its designee) with respect to any question arising out of or in connection with the administration, interpretation and application of this Agreement shall be final and conclusive and binding upon all persons having any interest in this Agreement. The Company shall indemnify and hold harmless the Plan Administrator and any Company employee to whom administrative duties under this Agreement are delegated, against any and all claims, loss, damage, expense or liability arising from any action or failure to act with respect to this Agreement, except in the case of gross negligence or willful misconduct by the Plan Administrator or any such employee.
perturbation.changed_text: 13. Administration. If this Agreement is determined to be subject to ERISA, it shall be administered by the Corporation, or its designee (the "Plan Supervisor"), which shall be the "named fiduciary" of this Agreement for purposes of ERISA. The Plan Supervisor shall have the authority to make, amend, interpret, and enforce all rules and regulations for the administration of this Agreement and decide or resolve any and all questions, including interpretations of the Agreement, as may arise in connection with this Agreement. In the administration of this Agreement, the Plan Supervisor from time to time may employ agents and delegate to them or to others (including executives of the Corporation) such administrative duties as it sees fit. The Plan Supervisor from time to time may consult with counsel, who may be counsel to the Corporation. The decision or action of the Plan Supervisor (or its designee) with respect to any question arising out of or in connection with the administration, interpretation and application of this Agreement shall be final and conclusive and binding upon all persons having any interest in this Agreement. The Corporation shall indemnify and hold harmless the Plan Supervisor and any Corporation employee to whom administrative duties under this Agreement are delegated, against any and all claims, loss, damage, expense or liability arising from any action or failure to act with respect to this Agreement, except in the case of gross negligence or willful misconduct by the Plan Supervisor or any such employee.
perturbation.explanation: Switching from 'Plan Administrator' to 'Plan Supervisor' and 'Company' to 'Corporation' without clarification creates uncertainty about who is responsible for administering the plan. Now the agreement refers to 'Company Employee' but tasks delegated to 'Corporation'. Which entity will indemnify the parties or their designees?
